ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
-Quantum Mechanics
-Statistical Thermodynamics
-Wave functions
-Periodic Trends and Shape
All about quantum mechanics and the physics of chemistry.
I gained a broad understanding of quantum mechanics and how it relates to chemical applications.
I learned that I should've taken differential equations. Learned a lot of math and quantum mech.
fundamentals of quantum mechanics from schrdinger's equation to the quantum behavior of bulk matter and statistical mechanics.

With the guidance of Professor Zilm, I learned the fundamentals of statistical mechanics and quantum chemistry. Additionally, I learned how to collaborate with others to better understand the material.

Using the knowledge from last semester in PChem, we built upon prior information and introduced a lot of quantum mechanical theory that I didn't know before taking the course. We ended with statistical mechanics and Professor Zilm does a great job at teaching this material.
I learned a lot about quantum mechanics and expanded my knowledge on chemistry
Greater understanding of quantum mechanics.
I learned about the development of quantum mechanical theory and how quantum mechanics gives rise to classical mechanics.
QR skills.
Quantum Mechanics, Kinetics, Bond theory
pchem
Quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics at an intro level
Quantum mechanics overview and introduction

I learned about the physics and math behind our modern understanding of the electron and the atom. We first looked at the shortcomings of classical mechanics and then derived Schrodinger's wave equations. We expanded these equations from first looking at a simple particle in a box to entire molecules with several modes of energy.
Knowledge of quantum and statistical mechanics as they pertains to chemistry and chemical reactions
In this class, I learned a lot of quantum mechanics. In addition, towards the end of the semester, statistical mechanics was taught.
Course focuses mainly on quantum mechanics, so if you were even minutely interested in how the world works, you will be hooked.
A quantitative treatment of fundamental principles in chemistry.
Topics in physical chemistry like quantum mechanics

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
-Organized
-Good lecture notes
-Nice professor

Weaknesses
-Difficult material

Strengths were definitely Prof. Zilm and the ta/peer tutors. The only weakness is it got confusing at times but that's from the nature of the subject. The shining star of the course was definitely Prof. Zilm. He's super knowledgeable and really cares about students and teaching. I loved that he made his lecture notes available because it made reviewing much easier.

The biggest strength of this course was Prof. Zilm being a very accommodating professor. His exam policy was fair and his grading policy/general attitude toward the class was effective in fostering a supportive and non-toxic environment among the class. I do think he could have gone a bit further with answering questions, as sometimes it just seemed like he repeated what was in the notes without really going into a deeper explanation. Also, the wording of question (especially on exams) was sometimes unclear, which did provide some general confusion at several points throughout the semester.

Strengths - Professor Zilm made this complicated class as straightforward as possible and really does want every student to do well. He posts clear lecture notes before lecture and gives study guides with topics and practice problems before exams. The psets are much less tedious than semester 1. Also unlike sem 1, there is no lecture during reading week, and the final is a midterm instead of cumulative. Other chem dpt classes (esp sem 1 pchem), take note! Still learned a lot but was less stressful.

Weaknesses - Lecture always went 20 minutes over time. Section was sometimes helpful, sometimes not at all. I never fully understood what was happening. Some problems were just going thru the motions bc I didn't fully understand the math or the conceptual background. I didn't take diff eq but feel like it would've been useful.

Overall, a solid intro to quantum mechancis and quantum chemistry. It was kind of frustrating that differential equations, multivariable calculus, and linear algebra concepts were used frequently despite not being prerequisites for the class.

The strengths of the course were the breadth of information we were exposed to and the relatively streamlined fashion in which information was delivered. Professor Zilm's notes were particularly useful when reviewing material because his lectures were essentially verbatim from the notes. That being said, because he was not really adding much to his notes, I found the lectures boring. His lectures could be improved if he presented the information more dynamically. The class was manageable but not particularly engaging.

The class was really fun to be in, very amazing professor and Teaching Fellows, super supportive of the learning process. Weekly sections were really helpful to finish the HW and understand/reinforce material from class.
I think Professor Zilm's lectures were interesting and found his lecture notes very helpful
strengths include the content material, explanations in lecture and the detailed lecture notes.

Strengths - interesting material, useful lecture notes, great peer tutors / TAs

Weaknesses - lectures could be confusing at times
I felt the course material was very interesting. Tests and homework were also straightforward. The only weakness of the course was that sometimes questions would be a little vague.
virtual worked great
Very organized lectures and corresponding notes.

I think that this course is really well taught, and I do like that we have four midterms instead of midterms and finals. There are times when the class went fast, but other than that, not too much to complain about.

This course was relatively well organized -- I really liked having the notes on Canvas to support lecture material. There were a lot of exams and the psets were challenging, but I'd say the exams were very fair and based on material that we learned during the course. Professor Zilm seemed engaging and understanding, and I appreciate that he cared about his students and wanted to help us do well.

Very interesting material and key to many core concepts in chemistry. However, it is very fast-paced and requires a solid understanding of multivariable calculus (which is surprisingly not a prerequisite to the CHEM major) to appreciate.
It was consistent and everybody involved in the course was as helpful as possible.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded lectures worked well

I appreciated having live lectures, as that certainly kept me more engaged with the class and motivated me to not fall behind. However, they were pretty inefficient and we went over time significantly every single class, which is definitely something I feel could have been improved upon.

Professor Zilm was understanding of the unprecedented circumstances. Keeping exams open for 12 hours and giving extra time was nice. Engagement in lecture and section was low but not really sure how that can be helped.

Recording the lectures and posting them on the media library were very helpful for understanding and for studying for tests, and it would be nice if this policy were kept after the return to in-person learning. The discussion section promoted engagement.
Having a longer time frame to complete tests (3 hour exam anytime between 9 AM and midnight) was extremely helpful. I felt less pressure because there was more flexibility.

Overall, Professor Zilm did an amazing job converting the learning experience virtually. I just wish there was a way to find other people in the class to create study groups but this is probably only a problem because of online classes this semester.
I think the live virtual lectures mirrored in class live lectures and liked that you could stop and ask questions throughout the lecture

The very detailed lecture notes and opportunity to ask questions at the end of lecture helped a good amount. Discussion sections could have been a little more clear, but were still helpful. Having more example problems in class would have been good.
I really enjoyed the course format.
all
The recorded lectures and peer tutoring was helpful. I also appreciated the PDF notes that I could look at while watching lecture.
I think that the recorded lecturers were helpful because Professor Zilm did mostly write really fast.

It was very difficult to be engaged in the course given the virtual instruction. Lectures were quite fast-paced for me, but there was also a lot of material to cover and peer tutors/TAs were a lot of help in supporting lecture material. I do wish that there were more examples done in lecture to help with  applying concepts to problems (like we were expected to do in our psets).
It was nice that the lectures were recorded so I could go back and watch them multiple times.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not unless required

If it's with Zilm please take this course if you have to. Even then, if you're just interested in Quantum Mechanics and chemistry take it. It was my hardest class ever but I really enjoyed learning a super interesting subject with great teaching staff.

If you aren't required to take this course, I probably would not recommend it. The class isn't unreasonably difficult and the content is interesting, but I don't think it is taught very clearly and I found myself to be confused for the vast majority of the semester. A lot of this I think is because of the teaching team and the way they organized the class, and you can certainly still do well, but it is overall probably going to be a fairly frustrating experience. If you only care about getting a solid grade, I'd definitely recommend it, but otherwise you may be better served looking at other options if you can before you make a decision.

No, mostly bc I didn't find the content that engaging, but, if you're required to take it, it really isn't that bad compared to sem 1. Read the class notes, go to peer tutors to get help on psets, do the exam review problems, and you'll be fine. Psets aren't tedious, exams are straightforward, and final isn't cumulative.
You likely are taking this because you have to, but, nevertheless, I would recommend this course to another student. The topic is fascinating and fundamental to the understanding of chemistry.

Unless this course in mandatory (e.g. chemistry major), I would not recommend this course. It's not particularly engaging, and there are many other chemistry classes that would be better choices. That being said, the material taught by Professor Zilm is foundational to understanding chemistry writ large, so if you're looking to develop a strong understanding of the field, then it may be worthwhile.

Take this class after PChem1 for the chemistry degree and you learn a lot of statistical/quantum mechanics. Lots of math required but it is well-explained and prior math knowledge other than multivariable calculus is needed.
If you're interested in quantum mechanics, then yes
Yes, I would recommend as the content is interesting and also since the class is a major requirement.
Yes - I feel like I have a much better understanding of the foundations of chemistry and bonding, and the material was very interesting, if sometimes very conceptual and hard to grasp.
Only people with interests in Chemistry.
Yes - keep up with the lectures, homework and the practice tests and the course should be very manageable.
yes
Yes. It was a well taught class and I thought I had a thorough understanding of the material.
Yes. Itll give you a good foundation in quantum and is reasonable in difficulty for a chem major

I would recommend this course if you are interested in the topic. As a chemical engineering major, I found everything we learned to be incredibly interesting, and I did not mind doing a lot of the work because I felt I was learning a lot. That being said, the material is very challenging and difficult to grasp without putting in a lot of work.
I would recommend this course. It is a great introduction to quantum mechanics in chemistry
I would recommend this course to another student, even if they are not in a STEM field. I think the grading is pretty generous, especially if you improve on your exam performance.
If you are very interested in physical chemistry and ready for a challenging course then yes, but it's a pretty tough class and very fast-paced so hard to absorb a lot.

Not if you do not have to, it's just difficult material and a lot of work. It is interesting how quantum mechanics explains chemistry and the elements as we know it in ways like the structure of the periodic table, but other than that it was a lot of pain and suffering.

Live section
recorded lecture.

There were also live virtual office hours held by peer tutors, TAs, and the professor.
live discussion sections
We also had weekly discussion sections with our TAs.
Discussion Section
amazing notes
Recorded the live lectures
Recorded lectures
I normally attended the live virtual lecture, but I would watch the recorded lectures if I missed a class or if I needed to review a topic.
Lectures were also recorded
The lectures were also recorded.
The lectures were recorded and posted on canvas for future viewings.
Lectures were recorded as well as in person, sections were live
Live virtual lectures coupled with recorded lectures and virtual discussion sections.
There were live lectures and they were also recorded
